column1: Matsumoto Yamaga Football Club (松本山雅フットボールクラブ
column2: Matsumoto Yamaga Futtobōru Kurabu) is the Japanese football (soccer) club based in Matsumoto
column3: Nagano Prefecture. The club currently plays in the J2 League. It was previously promoted to the J. League Division 1 in 2015 and 2019
column4: but was each time relegated after one season in the first tier of Japanese football.

column1: The mascot of the club is called "GANS KUN" (ガンズくん)
column2: which is related to the Ptarmigans (ターミガンズ

column1: The club was founded in 1965 by the players who represented Nagano Prefecture. The players frequented a cafe called Yamaga in front of Matsumoto railway station and initially they were simply called Yamaga Club. In 2004
column2: they were renamed as Matsumoto Yamaga FC when nonprofit organisation Alwin Sports Project were set up to support the club with the intention of promotion to J. League.

column1: In the 2007 and 2008 season they finished respectively 1st and 4th in the Hokushin'etsu First Division
column2: but failed to gain the promotion to the Japan Football League as they exited at the group stage of the Regional League promotion series against other regional champions. 2008 also brought a crucial Emperor's Cup run
column3: where they defeated former Japanese champions Shonan Bellmare in the third round by penalty kicks
column4: only to be eliminated 8–0 by Vissel Kobe.

column2: as they took 4th place in the regional league but knocked Urawa Red Diamonds out of the Emperor's Cup in the second round

column1: By virtue of winning the Shakaijin Cup
column2: they earned a berth in the Regional League promotion series
column3: and won the series at home to earn promotion to the Japan Football League for 2010. They earned 7th place on their first season in the third tier.

column2: despite a season thrown off by the Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami and the resulting inability of Sony Sendai to play a full schedule
column3: Yamaga earned 4th place and were promoted to J. League Division 2. After three seasons they earned their first ever promotion to J1 League
column4: only to be relegated after one season.

column1: After failing to secure promotion in 2016 and 2017
column2: Yamaga finished their 2018 season at the top of the J2 table
column3: winning their first ever league title and securing automatic promotion to J1 in the process.

column1: The biggest rival of Matsumoto Yamaga are the prefectural neighbors and former Hokushin'etsu League fellows Nagano Parceiro. Matches between those teams are labelled "Shinshū derby" and generate a lot of interest in both cities. For 2011 season
column2: Parceiro joined their rivals in JFL bringing the derby to the national level.

column1: Matsumoto Yamaga's home ground is Matsumoto Stadium (popularly known as Alwin) located in the Kambayashi area of Matsumoto city. The stadium has a capacity of 20
column4: 000 standings). It is the third largest Sport venue in Nagano Prefecture.
